data_clean module¶

class interactive_visuals.Interactive_Visuals(df)¶

Bases: object

This class allows creating dynamic visualizations that match ggplot’s format. Current options include the following:

  • Histogram

  • Bar chart

  • Scatterplot

  • Line chart

  • Control chart

barplot(x='Predictor', color=None, opacity=1, template='ggplot2', has_title=True, barmode='stack', is_horizontal=False, title=None, is_percent=False, show_num=False)¶

Creates a Plotly bar plot. Bar plots work with categorical data. Function computes appropriate counts and percentages to create bar plots.

Parameters

  • x (str) – Required. The name of a categorical variable in the data frame you want to be your predictor.

  • color (str) – Optional; default None. A factor variable that you want to visualize your bar plot.

  • is_horizontal (bool) – Optional, default False. Will swap x and y values so that the plot appears horizontally.

  • opacity (float) – Optional, default 1. The opacity of the bars in the histogram. Can be set between 0 and 1.

  • template (str) – Optional, default ggplot2 (chosen to align with R visualizations). Changes template of plot from default Plotly to another format.

  • barmode (str) – Optional, default “stack”. Options: [‘stack’, ‘group’, ‘overlay’, ‘relative’]

  • has_title (bool) – Optional, default True. Determines if plot has a title or not. Default title is provided if True, but can be customized with title.

  • title (str) – Optional, default None. Changes title of plot from the default.

  • is_percent (bool) – Optional, default False. Set true to plot a percentage-based stacked bar plot.

  • show_num (bool) – Optional, default False. Show percentages on stacked bar plot.

Returns

Plotly fig object

control_chart_ADTK(title='Control Chart Example', value_name='Actuals', y_axis_name='Percent')¶

Creates a Plotly control chart of a metric measured over time.

Parameters

  • df (Dataframe) –

    Required. Data frame fed in should have these columns:

    • Date (as index)

    • Values

    • Median

    • UCL

    • LCL

    • Violation (value between 0 and 1 returning the probability of a point being an outlier)

  • title (str) – A string that will define the title of your Control Chart. Default is “Control Chart Example”.

  • value_name (str) – A string that represent the name of the values in the control chart. Default is “Actuals”.

  • y_axis_name (str) – A string that represent the name of the values in the control chart. Default is “Actuals”.

Returns

Plotly fig object.

forecast_CV_surge(title='Cross-Validation', value_name='Actuals', upper_bound_name='Worst-Case', lower_bound_name='Best-Case', upper_bound_color='red', lower_bound_color='blue', predicted_color='orange', fill_color_and_opacity='rgba(50, 50, 50, .2)', roll_avg=False, roll_avg_num=7)¶

Creates a Plotly line chart of a metric alongside bounds and predicted values. Can be used for either cross-validation or forecasting.

Parameters

  • df (Dataframe) –

    Required to be fed into the class. Note for this, the data frame fed in should have these columns:

    • Date (as index)

    • Values (known, not forecasted)

    • Predicted (forecasted expected values)

    • UB (upper bound; ex: prediction interval 95%)

    • LB (lower bound)

  • title (str) – A string that will define the title of your graph. Default is “Cross-Validation”.

  • value_name (str) – A string that represent the name of the values in the graph. Default is “Actuals”.

  • upper_bound_name (str) – A string that represents the name of the upper bound in the graph. Default is “Worst-Case”.

  • lower_bound_name (str) – A string that represents the name of the lower bound in the graph. Default is “Best-Case”.

  • lower_bound_color (str) – A string that represents the color of the lower bound in the graph. Default is “blue”.

  • upper_bound_color (str) – A string that represents the color of the upper bound in the graph. Default is “red”.

  • predicted_color (str) – A string that represents the color of the predicted linke in the graph. Default is “orange”.

  • fill_color_and_opacity (str) – A string that represents the color and opacity of the fill. Default is ‘rgba(50,50,50.2)’, which creates a light gray tint between the lower and upper bounds. To make opacity clear and have no shading appear, set the final value in rgba to be 0.

  • roll_avg (bool) – Boolean to determine if need to apply rolling average to data.

  • roll_avg_num (int) – Integer indicating frequency to apply rolling average on. Default is 7.

Returns

Plotly fig object.

histogram(x='Predictor', y=None, is_horizontal=False, color=None, facet_col=None, facet_row=None, bins=20, opacity=1, marginal=None, template='ggplot2', has_title=True, title=None)¶

Creates a Plotly histogram. Plotly histograms can work with both numeric and categorical data.

Parameters

  • x (str) – Required. The name of a numeric variable in the data frame you want to be your predictor.

  • y (str) – Optional, default None. Using this may give weird and unexpected results, as Plotly tries to adapt to data fed in!

  • is_horizontal (bool) – Optional, default False. Will swap x and y values so that the plot appears horizontally.

  • color (str) – Optional; default None. A factor variable that you want to visualize your histogram.

  • facet_col (str) – Optional; default None. A factor variable you want to facet your histogram on vertically.

  • facet_row (str) – Optional; default None. A factor variable you want to facet your histogram on horizontally.

  • bins (int) – Optional; default 20. The number of bins you want your histogram to have.

  • opacity (float) – Optional, default 1. The opacity of the bars in the histogram. Can be set between 0 and 1.

  • marginal (str) – Optional; default None. Can set to “rug”, “box”, or “violin”.

  • template (str) – Optional, default ggplot2 (chosen to align with R visualizations). Changes template of plot from default Plotly to another format.

  • has_title (bool) – Optional, default True. Determines if plot has a title or not. Default title is provided if True, but can be customized with title.

  • title (str) – Optional, default None. Changes title of plot from the default.

Returns

Plotly fig object

linechart(x='Predictor', y='Response', color=None, template='ggplot2', has_title=True, title=None)¶

Creates a Plotly line chart of a numeric and date variable

Parameters

  • x (str) – Required. The name of a date variable in the data frame you want to be your predictor.

  • y (str) – Required. The name of a numeric variable in the data frame you want to be your response.

  • color (str) – Optional; default None. A variable that you want to visualize your scatterplot across. Can be numeric or factor.

  • template (str) – Optional, default ggplot2 (chosen to align with R visualizations). Changes template of plot from default Plotly to another format.

  • has_title (bool) – Optional, default True. Determines if plot has a title or not. Default title is provided if True, but can be customized with title.

  • title (str) – Optional, default None. Changes title of plot from the default.

Returns

Plotly fig object.

scatterplot(x='Predictor', y='Response', color=None, jitter=False, jitter_sd=0.1, marg_x=None, marg_y=None, trendline=None, opacity=1, template='ggplot2', has_title=True, title=None)¶

Creates a Plotly scatter plot of two numeric variables.

Parameters

  • x (str) – Required. The name of a numeric variable in the data frame you want to be your predictor.

  • y (str) – Required. The name of a numeric variable in the data frame you want to be your response.

  • jitter (bool) – Optional; default False. Setting to true adds noise to data to stop points from overlapping on each other.

  • jitter_sd (float) – Optional; default .1. Determines the variability of random noise applied to your data.

  • color (str) – Optional; default None. A variable that you want to visualize your scatterplot across. Can be numeric or factor.

  • marg_x (str) – Optional; default None. Set to either “histogram”, “box”, “rug”, or “violin” to visualize distribution of x variable.

  • marg_y (str) – Optional; default None. Set to either “histogram”, “box”, “rug”, or “violin” to visualize distribution of y variable.

  • opacity (float) – Optional, default 1. The opacity of the bars in the histogram. Can be set between 0 and 1.

  • trendline (str) – Optional, default None. Sets a trendline for scatterplot if “ols” is chosen. If categorical color chosen, will fit OLS to each factor of color.

  • template (str) – Optional, default ggplot2 (chosen to align with R visualizations). Changes template of plot from default Plotly to another format.

  • has_title (bool) – Optional, default True. Determines if plot has a title or not. Default title is provided if True, but can be customized with title.

  • title (str) – Optional, default None. Changes title of plot from the default.

Returns

Plotly fig object.
